content.text: Our new book In the Bonesetter’s Waiting Room by Aarathi Prasad was inspired by Wellcome Collection’s 2016 Mumbai exhibition and broader programme of events exploring India’s rich plurality of cultures of medicine, healing and well-being. Using her own pictures from her travels, here’s a taste of Aarathi’s story of the Indian people, in sickness and in health, providing a unique perspective […]

On 60-feet Road, the main road into the Dharavi mega-slum, medical practitioners of various backgrounds offer a variety of services. This might include conventional medicine, but may also include Unani medicine, which can include the practice of bone-setting.

Houses in Dharavi consist of a downstairs room less than three metres squared which is used as a kitchen and sleeping area. If a family can afford it they will build an upstairs, accessed by a very steep metal ladder fixed to the outside of the property: a frequent cause of strains, sprains and breakages. As space is so tight in Dharavi, the upper floor can sometimes be used to generate a rental income.

None of the houses in this mega-slum have their own water supply or toilet facilities. Residents instead must use communal services: foul, over-used (and under-maintained) toilets via narrow, unlit alleyways. This is a cause of great concern, especially to women and children needing to access these facilities at night.
Enlarge the images in the gallery below to read more.

The Fish-medicine Doctors of Hyderabad. Every year, tens of thousands of young Murrell fish are set aside by Hyderabad's Fisheries Department, for patients to purchase for around 10 pence. The wriggling fish delivers the herbal paste into the throats of patients. For legal reasons, the giving of the fish and herbs is called prasadam, which refers to a blessed food, getting round any problems of distributing an unlicensed medicine. In India, there are many opponents to this ceremony, but year on year thousands more people come to the Bathini Goud doctors for treatment.

The Fish-medicine Doctors of Hyderabad. Before the annual ceremony, in which the herbal paste is put into the mouth of a small Murrell fish and swallowed by patients seeking relief from asthma, the Bathini Goud family offer prayers in the ornate temple they built adjacent to their ancestral home.

City Market, Bangalore (Bengaluru). In City Market, an expansive street market in Bangalore, you can buy almost anything. There are a wide range of medical products on offer too, and the services of a famous street dentist, who sets up a parasol, a barber's chair and a cart displaying his dental tools, dentures and fixtures. He is normally never short of clients.

The cost of medicines in India. The cost of medicines in India can be prohibitively expensive for the country's poor but can also place an immense strain on the middle-classes. Eighty per cent of people pay out of their own pockets for medical care – around seventy percent of which is spent on just buying necessary medications. It is also estimated that annually around forty million people are forced into poverty solely because of the quest to find funds for their health. In answer to providing affordable health care, India is the home of a substantial generic-drugs industry, which also then supplies low-cost medicines to other countries, including many in sub-Saharan Africa. But producing low-cost drugs is not as easy a solution as it seems. A 2015 FT report described how 'Western drug-makers have accused India of abusing their intellectual property to benefit local generic manufacturers, while Indian authorities and activists have accused foreign companies of defending spurious patents to keep drugs out of reach of the poor.' But solutions are always being sought. This is an advertisement for 1mg, a comprehensive health platform available as an app that provides information on (AYUSH and western) medicines and offers more competitively priced alternatives. It also connects patients to AYUSH and mainstream doctors, all of whom are rated, and sells health products and medications - including antibiotics - for home delivery.

Some specialised families of Hakims in Hyderabad also practise bone-setting, in which severe muscle strains, closed fractures and broken bones are worked on. Hakim Gulam Mohideen [pictured] is a ninth-generation bone-setter. His ancestors were also physicians to Emperor Aurangzeb, who besieged and conquered Hyderabad's 'impenetrable' fortress in 1687. Soldiers' injuries were treated by bone-setting and the use of herbal pastes (lep), which to this day are closely held family secrets.

Dr Shroff's Charity Eye Hospital in Daryaganj. In 2002, shortly after the hospital opened its paediatric facility, Professor Pawan Sinha started Project Prakash from a wing of the Dr Shroff's Charity hospital. The Project has two aims, to cure children’s blindness, and to illuminate some of the most fundamental questions of how the brain learns to see. Professor Sinha and his team have since worked with over 40,000 children who live below the poverty line.

Dr Shroff's Charity Eye Hospital in Daryaganj. Today, India is still home to the largest population of blind people in the world. The reasons for this include a lack of adequately trained medical staff, unaffordable treatment for those who need it most, malnutrition, untreated chronic disease and belatedly introduced vaccination programmes. Poor people who are also blind find themselves stuck in a pernicious cycle of poverty. Unable to receive an education, the prospects for poor children who are blind are particularly tragic, with girls suffering the most. Estimates of the number of blind children in India range from 200,000 to 700,000.

Dr Shroff's Charity Eye Hospital in Daryaganj. In 1914, Dr S.P. Shroff returned to India after receiving his FRCS (Fellow of the Royal College of Surgeons) in London. Wanting to offer free, high-quality eye care to Delhi's poor, he created the Dr Shroff's Charity Eye Hospital in Daryaganj, in 1927. It was inaugurated by Lady Irwin, wife of the then Viceroy of India, and has since provided services to its community and to those unable to pay from many of the largely rural states surrounding India's capital.

Gadchiroli. At the entrance to the tribal hospital stands an image of the Goddess worshipped by the Gond Tribes. Called Danteshwari, she is an incarnation of the wife of the god Shiva. When Dr Rani Bang asked why they had requested this temple, they said, ‘in modern hospitals you doctors think you are the gods. But we have faith in our goddess, so we will first visit our goddess and then visit you. So the temple sits just by the front gates. And the inauguration of the hospital was done by the main priest of the group of sixty or seventy villages. In that inaugural speech the tribal leader said that this hospital does not belong to the prime minister; it doesn’t belong to the president of India, this doesn’t belong to Rani Bang, it is our hospital. And every year we have that tribal assembly still.’

Gadchiroli. Behind the tribal hospital, in amongst the trees are scattered further buildings in the style of tribal huts. They include researchers' offices and a computer science/statistics hut, where data gathered from local health programmes are analysed. There is also a gallery which showcases art made by local tribespeople.

Gadchiroli. Initially, the locals had expressed a great distrust of doctors. From 1993 the couple began working with their tribal neighbours to design a hospital that would be built around their needs and take into account the local culture. At its centre was a gotkul, a key structure in their villages that served as a community centre where teenagers gather for dances and families meet and talk. The hospital's 'gotkul' was a courtyard surrounded by a few small buildings: a medicine dispensary, an education centre, a GP surgery. The wards, high-tech operating theatres and family accommodation surround that central space.

Gadchiroli. Since 1986, Dr Rani and Abhay Bang have been working in the remote forest areas of Gadchiroli, home to the Gond tribes. They found a desperate lack of high-quality health care and public health programmes, and responded by creating a toolkit and educational programme to train local men and women as primary healthcare providers. Their model of home-based newborn care, which massively reduced infant deaths in rural areas, was accepted by the World Health Organisation and adopted in other parts of the subcontinent and has since been used in several sub-Saharan African countries.

Bone-setting. Some specialised families of Hakims in Hyderabad also practise bone-setting, in which severe muscle strains, closed fractures and broken bones are worked on. Hakim Gulam Mohideen [pictured] is a ninth-generation bone-setter. His ancestors were also physicians to Emperor Aurangzeb, who besieged and conquered Hyderabad's 'impenetrable' fortress in 1687. Soldiers' injuries were treated by bone-setting and the use of herbal pastes (lep), which to this day are closely held family secrets. Khaja Mohd Azeem Uddin is Hyderabad's last practitioner of Tibb-e-Nabawi, an Islamic system of medicine. Some of his herbal formulations use herbs brought from Mecca, others parallel plants used in Unani and Ayurveda.

Hakim Sultan Rasool. Before Government-run Ayurveda and Unani training colleges, the practice of these systems was passed down through families or gurukulas (vocational schools in which boys were apprenticed from a young age). Many graduates of the new colleges find it difficult to establish themselves enough to make a living income, but the practices of old family Hakims and Vaidyas (Unani / Ayurveda doctors) are thriving. Hakim Sultan Rasool was one of those doctors. He took me on a trip to the outskirts of Hyderabad to show me the medicinal plants that can be found almost everywhere, ones he experiments with as new treatments for his patients’ conditions.

AYUSH. Unani is one of the state-approved systems of medicine, recognised under the Government's Department of AYUSH. As with Ayurveda, there are state-funded hospitals and research facilities which cultivate its herbs and employ chemists and geneticists to study the mode of action and efficacy through methods which parallel modern biomedical analyses and clinical trials.

Unani. The theory of Unani is based on the ideas of the ancient Greek physician Hippocrates, but evolved and developed through the scholarship of doctors throughout the mediaeval Arabic world, with input from other medical systems, including Ayurveda. Its medicines are naturally derived, and its diagnostics now incorporate tools used in modern Western medical practice.

Tibb-e-Nabawi. Khaja Mohd Azeem Uddin is Hyderabad's last practitioner of Tibb-e-Nabawi, an Islamic system of medicine. Some of his herbal formulations use herbs brought from Mecca, others parallel plants used in Unani and Ayurveda.

The Fish-medicine Doctors of Hyderabad. The Fish-medicine Doctors of Hyderabad still live in the village where their family built their home 170 years ago. The village is now enveloped by the metropolis, but has a mediaeval feel, with narrow streets and historic buildings of European and Islamic style crammed in over the past two centuries. They remain in Doodhbowli because of the well in the courtyard of their home, blessed by a holy man in 1845, from which water to make their secret herbal paste is taken.

Aarathi Prasad is a biologist and writer.
